scenarioDescription:
The HIP 70849 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HIP 70849 is a star with 0.63 times the mass of the Sun, and NaN times its radius. It is located 78.46 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 3 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HIP 70849 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HIP 70849 system


HIP 70849 b

HIP 70849 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2011-11, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 20.25 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 70849 b is 2862.000 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 70849 b is 12.500 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HIP 70849 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system HIP 70849, which contains 1 exoplanets and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: HIP 70849 - System With 1 Exoplanet
